abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Natural Resources
            Management Project in Mali is satisfactory with likely
            sustainability, high institutional development impact and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and the Borrower.
            The project met the overarching objective of introducing a
            rational land use system. Project components were modified
            by splitting the Institutional Support for Government
            Services from the Environmental Information Services
            component; expanding from 150 to 600 to 844 the targeted
            villages, while at the same time quartering the amount per
            village and curtailing funding of social investments; and
            adding communes to villages. The two aspects of the
            components not completed were the opening of a boundary
            trail and implementation of the park management plan within
            the Baoule National Park. Lessons learned include: the
            importance of listening and working with stakeholders using
            participatory approaches; assessments and feedback need to
            be backed with tangible data; economic and financial rates
            of return need to be included in the design of monitoring
            and evaluation; literacy is a necessary condition;
            government, non-government, and private agencies play a
            complementary role in assistance to local communities;
            decentralization must be accompanied by deconcentration of
            government services; regular supervision missions are
            essential; and monitoring and evaluation should remain
            simple and integrated while involving decision makers at
            every level.
